content: apologies, won't be able to make meeting today
@T-infra T-5 minutes for the meeting
@T-infra meeting time!
ok let's start!
we have two P-high issues
both of those were stable-to-beta regressions related to ./x.py install
both of them are fixed on nightly but await a backport to beta

x.py install doesn't install binaries. #80683
x.py install fails when run outside of Rust source directory #80494
I think I ran out out of time this last weekend for those backports, but adding that to my todo list this time around.
I'd say let's wait for the release team to backport them, but otherwise no action on our end
there are no other issues for us to look at, so let's move to the agenda!
both of the items here were brought up by the core team for the needs of the foundation
the first one is "Infrastructure for @rust-lang.org email addresses for contributors"
this proposal is to basically have email addresses like pietroalbini@rust-lang.org for a set of team members
who gets them will be a question for the core team imo, but there is a strong need to have something like this
How self-run do we want?
e.g. is "Google donates a Google Suite account" on the table?
or whatever the name of that product is
as a datapoint, ashley really needed her @rust-lang.org email address for foundation work, and I hacked something up a couple days ago for it

Jake Goulding said:

e.g. is "Google donates a Google Suite account" on the table?

yes!
or well, if we don't get a donation the team can make a strong case for the foundation to buy it on its own
(that feels good to write!)
so it won't be just an address forwarding to personal mailbox
I think we need to make that choice

what I would expect for the infra team to decide is (in order of priority):

  1. what schema we want for the addresses (githubusername@, first.last@...)
  2. what's the general shape of the services we want to provide (for example forwarding vs full mailbox)
  3. the actual implementation / service we use
what process would you suggest for these?
(i.e. debate now?)
so, I think it'd be good to narrow down to a couple (or just one!) of possibilities now during the meeting
and then make the final decision next week, so folks that were not here (aidan and other members of the community) can chime in
for 1. maybe we could let the contributor choose?
for 1. I think my worry with username is we're likely going to want to set up forwarding for either of the two suggested options when things change
which is fine - I actually suspect names change more often than usernames
if using Google Suite you could assign multiple aliases to the same user
I guess I'd just say we can probably use ghusername or so, for those with github, and leave it at that
(likely true for all other services too)
I'd expect that naming to be a personal choice. I'd prefer my real name, I know others wouldn't.
that's a good point, and honestly I didn't even consider it much before now
I guess I value(d) consistency
There's also changing values over time (people pick new names, both real and github)
I think mildly suggesting github username as being an alias is good
whether it's primary or not
there's lots of good to being able to say "I can email anyone in rust org without a lookup in some database"
Yes, suggesting a default of github username is reasonable.
and I guess if we set a policy here it's also good precedent for other stuff like aws accounts or shell access

there's lots of good to being able to say "I can email anyone in rust org without a lookup in some database"

LOL, this was going to be my prime example of why we might want _another_ identifier :-)
(I'm mildly worried about harassment avenues)
yeah I'm personally a fan of letting people pick whatever
but also alias ghusername@ for where it exists, unless they ask us not to

simulacrum said:

yeah I'm personally a fan of letting people pick whatever

question: so, for example, we'll allow picking firstname@ for the first people who request it? (like pietro@rust-lang.org)

sounds reasonable to me:

  1. you get ghusername by default, can opt-out
  2. you can add (one? a small number?) of aliases

If your alias conflicts with someones ghusername, you lose it to them :wink:
yeah, conflicts might be a thing. I know my university came up with mrousskov3 (though I honestly have a hard time believing there was 2-3 predecessors)
Should we have an alias squatting policy /s
namespace it :upside_down:
I think first come first serve, or otherwise under core's discretion or so seems fine for now
kennytm@shepmaster.rust-lang.org
we'll also want a policy for the future in terms of what happens when people leave/get banned
in a corporate structure, I'd say that email should go to the manager for a time period after leaving
so maybe to the team lead or team group email
that can be tricky
I think we can figure out on a case-by-case basis, we should just make sure system is designed to handle it ok

Jake Goulding said:

so maybe to the team lead or team group email

there are people who accidentally end up joining the "who's member of more teams" contest, and I know that for a fact because that happened with myself :upside_down:
I'd be tempted to say "just bounce those emails"

Pietro Albini said:

I'd be tempted to say "just bounce those emails"

I could see us wanting e.g password reset or so, for cases where a rust-lang-owner account is complicated or not possible
but generally, yes

simulacrum said:

Pietro Albini said:

I'd be tempted to say "just bounce those emails"

I could see us wanting e.g password reset or so, for cases where a rust-lang-owner account is complicated or not possible

sure, but like, in those cases we can temporary re-create the mailbox
yeah
I just mean that there should be no expectation that you leaving means no one will see incoming mail
(or, for that matter, during your presence, since we can't avoid it for legal reasons in some cases)
yeah, I would expect that @rust-lang.org emails should only be used for project stuff (i.e. not using it as your main mail) and to adhere to the CoC when using it
yep, that would make sense to me.
expect => put in a document with the rest of this :-)

simulacrum said:

but also alias ghusername@ for where it exists, unless they ask us not to

last thing I'd want to say, I'm not sure opting out of ghusername@ is something we'll want to allow

Jake Goulding said:

expect => put in a document with the rest of this :-)

definitely

Pietro Albini said:

last thing I'd want to say, I'm not sure opting out of ghusername@ is something we'll want to allow

it will make things weird for people, and if they start getting harassed we can block the senders or temporarily disable the mailbox
also because if they're using the github username to harass someone... well... they can do the same on github
Yeah I don't expect it to be a thing
it's more so that e.g. our lawyer might not want to be associated with a personal github or something
and while these aren't... really public, it's awkward to rely on that
hmm
I'd expect foundation staff to be under a different policy than the rest of the project
oh yeah, people who arent on github
can one contribute and not be on github :thinking:
but then they can't join a team
at least with the current setup for the whole team management thing
ok
not really important
so

Each person will have githubusername@rust-lang.org, and they will be able to choose a custom alias on a first-come first-serve basis. In case of naming conflicts the Core Team will make a the final decision.

The mailbox will be disabled after someone leaves the project. The mailbox should only be used for project business, the CoC will adhere to communications sent through it (as you represent the project with that email) and it might be accessed by members of the project with elevated privileges if the need arises.
do we have consensus on this?
I think "infra or legal" might be too small, but it's not the most important thing - it's basically project property is the idea.
better @simulacrum?
sure.
ok then!
I'll add this to an issue, and we'll approve or tweak it next week
the second point to discuss is what we want the address to be

the options that come to mind are:
a. receive-only forwarding
b. forwarding with separate smtp credentials to send
c. full mailbox
I think we need at least b
Yeah, gotta be able to send from it IMO
personally I'd say (c) is better
I am inclined to say the difference between b and c is going to come down to what provider we use. I think c is the best, but if it's complicated, b is sufficient
but I'm not sure how much of an hassle it will be for people to check a separate mailbox
i.e. we must have b but c is ideal
folks should be able to setup forwarding themselves from almost any mailbox
(I'd guess that's like standard functionality)
that's true
any opinion on this @Jake Goulding @kennytm?
LGTM
I already have 3-4 mail accounts, so for me it's fine.

ok so I have

We need both the ability to send and receive emails. It's preferred to have a full mailbox, but if the service we end up using doesn't support it a forwarding alias with SMTP credentials could also work.
which I think covers everything
ok then, then the last question is what we'd actually want to use
or actually, wait
does anyone else have separate decisions they think should be made before the vendors? @triagebot await

Does anyone have something to add on the current topic?
React with :working_on_it: if you have something to say.
React with :all_good: if not.
(I think that should be the last)
@simulacrum?
ok then!
what do y'all think should be used for this?
I'm really against running our own mailserver for the record
DKIM SPDF OHNO
rewrite mail server in Rust, then host it ourselves?
I'm happy with gsuite or whatever, only hosted thing I've used though
I personally think it would be a great opportunity to start using one of the big hosted suites
as that could also be a way to eventually standardize video call software, documents storage, mailing list with archives, SSO, etc
and I'd personally lean torwards gsuite as that's what some teams at least are using for document storage already (plus msteams is... not the best in my personal opinion)
but I don't think which hosted vendor we integrate with matters too much
if we want to go with one
Too bad there's no real solution that's not one of the existing 800-lb gorillas

so, is something like this a preliminar consensus?

We won't manage our own mail server. Using a service that provides a full suite of services (mail, document collaboration, storage, video calls, SSO) is preferred to reduce the amount of tools we have to manage. Some members of the team have a slight leaning torwards GSuite.
"won't" is strong, but if that's what is meant, I'm fine with it
it's a "Pietro refuses to run it, volunteers?"
mostly
ran enough mail servers in my life
I figured :wink:
@simulacrum?
no thoughts
ok then!
I'll record this in an issue and forward it to aidan so he can look at it before next meeting
there is another small update I want to make
the core team also feels the need for private data in the team repository
I opened https://github.com/rust-lang/team/pull/515 as a stopgap to solve the urgent problem, but core is gonna prepare a set of directions for the future of the team repo
and we're out of time!
thanks everyone for attending!
clearly the data is bank account numbers to send us huge amounts of :money:

@Aidan Hobson Sayers you might want to check the full backscroll, but the main topic we talked about was inboxes for team members, and a general summary is available here: https://github.com/rust-lang/infra-team/issues/38
my plan is to talk about it again next week, to hopefully reach full consensus
